facts.text: Appeal is Criminal Appeal No. 7 of 1953 by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 7 of 1953. Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order of the High Court of Judicature at Nagpur dated the 15th. September, 1952, in Criminal Case No. 45 of 1951 from the Order of the Court of the Magistrate 1st Class, Hoshangabad, in Criminal Case No. 75 of 1949.

facts.text: High Court of Judicature at Nagpur delivered Judgment and Order dated 15th September 1952 in Criminal Case No. 45 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order of the High Court of Judicature at Nagpur dated the 15th. September, 1952, in Criminal Case No. 45 of 1951 from the Order of the Court of the Magistrate 1st Class, Hoshangabad, in Criminal Case No. 75 of 1949.

facts.text: Order from Court of Magistrate 1st Class, Hoshangabad in Criminal Case No. 75 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: dated the 15th. September, 1952, in Criminal Case No. 45 of 1951 from the Order of the Court of the Magistrate 1st Class, Hoshangabad, in Criminal Case No. 75 of 1949. J. Umrigar, Rameshwarnath and Rajinder Narain for the appellants.

facts.text: Appellants Harishankar Bagla and Smt. Gomti Bagla arrested at Itarsi by Railway Police on 29th November 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by MEHAR CHAND MAHAJAN C.J.--The facts giving rise to this appeal are these The appellant, Harishankar Bagla, and his wife, Smt. Gomti Bagla, were arrested at Itarsi, by the Railway Police on the 29th November, 1948, for contravention of section 7 of the Essential Supplies  Temporary Powers  Act, 1946, read with clause  3  of the Cotton Textiles  Control of Movement  Order., 1948, having been found in possession of new cotton cloth weighing over six maunds which cloth, it was alleged,was being taken by them from Bombay to Kanpur without any permit.

facts.text: Appellants found in possession of new cotton cloth weighing over six maunds.

anchor.surface_text: for contravention of section 7 of the Essential Supplies  Temporary Powers  Act, 1946, read with clause  3  of the Cotton Textiles  Control of Movement  Order., 1948, having been found in possession of new cotton cloth weighing over six maunds which cloth, it was alleged,was being taken by them from Bombay to Kanpur without any permit.

facts.text: Cloth was being taken by appellants from Bombay to Kanpur without any permit.

anchor.surface_text: having been found in possession of new cotton cloth weighing over six maunds which cloth, it was alleged,was being taken by them from Bombay to Kanpur without any permit. After various vicissitudes through which the chalan passed the case was eventually withdrawn by the High Court to itself on the 3rd of September,1951, as it involved a decision of constitutional issues.

facts.text: High Court withdrew the case to itself on 3rd September 1951.

anchor.surface_text: After various vicissitudes through which the chalan passed the case was eventually withdrawn by the High Court to itself on the 3rd of September,1951, as it involved a decision of constitutional issues. By its order dated the 15th September, 1952, the High Court upheld the provisions of sections 3 and 4 of the Essential Supplies  Temporary Powers  Act, 1946, as constitutional.

facts.text: High Court by order dated 15th September 1952 upheld sections 3 and 4 of Essential Supplies Temporary Powers Act 1946 as constitutional.

anchor.surface_text: By its order dated the 15th September, 1952, the High Court upheld the provisions of sections 3 and 4 of the Essential Supplies  Temporary Powers  Act, 1946, as constitutional. It also upheld the constitutionality of the impugned Order.

facts.text: High Court held section 6 of the Act inconsistent with Railway Act but unconstitutionality does not affect prosecution.

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 of the Act was held to be inconsistent with the provisions of the Railway Act but it was held that its unconstitutionality did number affect the prosecution in this case. The High Court directed that the prosecution should proceed and the records sent back to the trial Court for being dealt with in accordance with law.

facts.text: High Court directed prosecution to proceed and records sent back to trial court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court directed that the prosecution should proceed and the records sent back to the trial Court for being dealt with in accordance with law. Leave to appeal was given both to the appellants and the respondent and requisite certificates under articles 132 and 134 of the Constitution were granted.

facts.text: Leave to appeal granted to appellants and respondent with certificates under articles 132 and 134.

anchor.surface_text: Leave to appeal was given both to the appellants and the respondent and requisite certificates under articles 132 and 134 of the Constitution were granted. This appeal along with the connected appeal No. 6 of 1953 is before us on the basis of the said certificates.

facts.text: Central Government promulgated Cotton Textiles Control of Movement Order 1948 on 10th September 1948 under powers conferred by section 3.

anchor.surface_text: Under powers conferred by section 3 the Central Government promulgated on 10th September, 1948, Cotton Textiles  Control of Movement  Order, 1948. Section2 of this order defines the expressions apparel, carrier, hosiery, cloth and textile commissioner.

facts.text: Appellants never applied for a permit.

anchor.surface_text: In the first place, the appellants never applied for a permit and made number efforts to obtain one. If the permit had been applied for and refused arbitrarily they might then have had a right to attack the law on A.T.R. 1954 S.C. 225 1954 S.C.R. 80o3.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds sections 3 and 4 of Essential Supplies Temporary Powers Act 1946 constitutional.

anchor.surface_text: Sections 3 and 4 of the Essential Supplies  Temporary Powers  Act, 1946, provide as follows- 3.  1  The Central Government, so far as it appears to it to be necessary or expedient for maintaining or increasing supplies of any essential commodity, or for securing their equitable distribution and availability at fair prices, may by order provide for regulating or prohibiting the production, supply and distribution thereof and trade and commerce therein Without prejudice to the generality of the powers conferred by sub-section  1 , an order made thereunder may provide-

facts.text: Supreme Court holds section 6 of the Act constitutional.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, we are of the opinion that the High Court was in error in declaring section 6 of the Act unconstitutional.

facts.text: Supreme Court upholds Cotton Textiles Control of Movement Order 1948 as constitutional.

anchor.surface_text: The result therefore is that in our opinion the provisions of sections 3, 4 and 6 of the Essential Supplies  Temporary Powers  Act, 1946, are constitutional and. the impugned order is also constitutional.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on May 14 1954 by MEHAR CHAND MAHAJAN C.J.

anchor.surface_text: 1954. May 14. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by MEHAR CHAND MAHAJAN C.J.--The facts giving rise to this appeal are these The appellant, Harishankar Bagla, and his wife, Smt. Gomti Bagla, were arrested at Itarsi, by the Railway Police on the 29th November, 1948,

facts.text: Case involves contravention of section 7 of Essential Supplies Temporary Powers Act 1946 read with clause 3 of Cotton Textiles Control of Movement Order 1948.

anchor.surface_text: for contravention of section 7 of the Essential Supplies  Temporary Powers  Act, 1946, read with clause  3  of the Cotton Textiles  Control of Movement  Order., 1948, having been found in possession of new cotton cloth weighing over six maunds which cloth, it was alleged,was being taken by them from Bombay to Kanpur without any permit.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal along with the connected appeal No. 6 of 1953 is before us on the basis of the said certificates. Mr. Umrigar, who appeared in this and the connected appeal, urged the following points for our consideration and decision

facts.text: Appellants argued sections 3 and 4 and Control Order contravene article 19(1)(f) and (g).

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Umrigar, who appeared in this and the connected appeal, urged the following points for our consideration and decision That sections 3 and 4 of the Essential Supplies  Temporary Powers  Act, 1946, and the provisions of the Cotton Cloth Control Order contravened the fundamental right of the appellants guaranteed by article 19 1  f  and  g  of the Constitution

facts.text: Petitioner argued excessive delegation in section 3 and 4.

anchor.surface_text: That section 3 of the Essential Supplies  Temporary Powers  Act, 1946, and in particular section 4 were ultra vires, the Legislature on the ground of excessive delegation of legislative power

facts.text: Respondent challenged High Court finding that section 6 unconstitutional.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent challenged the judgment of the High Court that section 6 of the Act was unconstitutional.

facts.text: Section 3(1) empowers Central Government to regulate essential commodities for maintaining supplies, equitable distribution at fair prices.

anchor.surface_text: Sections 3 and 4 of the Essential Supplies  Temporary Powers  Act, 1946, provide as follows- 3.  1  The Central Government, so far as it appears to it to be necessary or expedient for maintaining or increasing supplies of any essential commodity, or for securing their equitable distribution and availability at fair prices, may by order provide for regulating or prohibiting the production, supply and distribution thereof and trade and commerce therein

facts.text: Section 4 allows Central Government to delegate powers under section 3 to subordinate officers or state governments.

anchor.surface_text: The Central Government may by notified order direct that the power to make orders under section 3 shall,in relation to such matters and subject to such conditions, if any, as may be specified in the direction, be exercisable also by-  a  such officer or authority subordinate to the Central Government, or  b  such State Government or such officer or authority subordinate to a State Government as may be specified in the direction.

facts.text: Clause 3 of Control Order prohibits transport of cloth, yarn or apparel without permit.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 of the order runs as follows- No person. shall transport or cause to be transported by rail, road, air, sea or inland navigation any cloth, yarn or apparel except under and in accordance with- a general permit notified in the Gazette of India by the Textile Commissioner, or a special transport permit issued by the Textile Commissioner.

issues.text: Whether sections 3 and 4 of the Essential Supplies Temporary Powers Act, 1946, and the provisions of the Cotton Cloth Control Order contravene the fundamental right of the appellants guaranteed by article 19(1)(f) and (g) of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Umrigar, who appeared in this and the connected appeal, urged the following points for our consideration and decision That sections 3 and 4 of the Essential Supplies  Temporary Powers  Act, 1946, and the provisions of the Cotton Cloth Control Order contravened the fundamental right of the appellants guaranteed by article 19 1  f

issues.text: Whether section 3 of the Essential Supplies Temporary Powers Act, 1946, and in particular section 4, are ultra vires the Legislature on the ground of excessive delegation of legislative power?

anchor.surface_text: That section 3 of the Essential Supplies  Temporary Powers  Act, 1946, and in particular section 4 were ultra vires, the Legislature on the ground of excessive delegation of legislative power That section 6 having been found ultra vires, section 3 was inextricably connected with it and that both the sections should have been declared ultra vires on that ground and That the impugned Control Order contravened existing laws, viz., the provisions of section 27,28 and 41 of the Indian Railways Act, and was thus void in its entirety.

issues.text: Whether, section 6 having been found ultra vires, section 3 was inextricably connected with it such that both sections should be declared ultra vires?

anchor.surface_text: That section 6 having been found ultra vires, section 3 was inextricably connected with it and that both the sections should have been declared ultra vires on that ground and That the impugned Control Order contravened existing laws, viz., the provisions of section 27,28 and 41 of the Indian Railways Act, and was thus void in its entirety. The respondent challenged the judgment of the High Court that section 6 of the Act was unconstitutional.

issues.text: Whether the impugned Control Order contravenes sections 27, 28 and 41 of the Indian Railways Act and is thus void in its entirety?

anchor.surface_text: That the impugned Control Order contravened existing laws, viz., the provisions of section 27,28 and 41 of the Indian Railways Act, and was thus void in its entirety. The respondent challenged the judgment of the High Court that section 6 of the Act was unconstitutional. In our judgment, none of the points raised by Mr. Umrigar have any validity.

issues.text: Whether section 6 of the Essential Supplies Temporary Powers Act, 1946, is unconstitutional?

anchor.surface_text: The respondent challenged the judgment of the High Court that section 6 of the Act was unconstitutional. In our judgment, none of the points raised by Mr. Umrigar have any validity. On the other hand, we are of the opinion that the High Court was in error in declaring section 6 of the Act unconstitutional.

issues.text: Whether the Textile Commissioner has been given unregulated and arbitrary discretion to refuse or grant permits under section 3 of the Control Order?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Umrigar further argued that the Textile Commissioner had been given unregulated and arbitrary discretion to refuse or to grant a permit, and that on grounds similar to those on which in Dwarka Prasad v. The State of Uttar Pradesh 1 , this Court declared void section 4 3  of the Uttar Pradesh Coal Control Order, section 3 of the Control Order in question should also be declared void.

arguments.claim: Provisions of section 3 of Control Order do not infringe Art 19(1)(f) and (g)

anchor.surface_text: The first question canvassed by Mr. Umrigar was that the provisions of section 3 of the Control Order infringed the rights of a citizen guaranteed in subclauses  f  and  g  of article 19 1  of the Constitution. These sub-clauses recognise the right of a citizen to dispose of property and to carry on trade or business.

arguments.claim: Delegation under section 3 valid as policy laid down

anchor.surface_text: In the first place, the appellants never applied for a permit and made number efforts to obtain one. ... The policy underlying the Order is to regulate the transport of companyton textile in a manner that will ensure an even distribution of the companymodity in the companyntry and make it available at a fair price to all.

Section 4 of the Act was attacked... The decision of their Lordships of the Privy Council in Shannons case  3 , companypletely negatives the companytention raised regarding the invalidity of section 4.

arguments.claim: Control Order does not imply repeal of Railways Act sections

anchor.surface_text: The next companytention that the provisions of the Textile Control Order operate as an implied repeal of sections 27, 28 and 41 of the Indian Railways Act and are therefore invalid is also number well founded.

arguments.claim: Section 6 constitutional; no delegation of repeal power

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, we are of the opinion that the High Court was in error in declaring section 6 of the Act unconstitutional. ... Section 6 does number either expressly or by implication repeal any of the provisions of pre-existing laws

holdings.text: The requirement of a permit in this regard cannot be regarded as an unreasonable restriction on the citizens right under sub-clauses f and g of article 19 1

anchor.surface_text: The requirement of a permit in this regard cannot be regarded as an unreasonable restriction on the citizens right under sub-clauses  f  and  g  of article 19 1 . If transport of essential companymodities by rail or other means of companyveyance was left uncontrolled it might well have seriously hampered the supply of these companymodities to the public.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Permit requirement imposes restriction but is reasonable under Art 19(5) in public interest for equitable distribution and availability at fair prices of essential commodities during emergency; uncontrolled transport would hamper supply.

holdings.text: section 3 of the Essential Supplies Temporary Powers Act, 1946, [does not amount to] delegation of Legislative power outside the permissible limits

anchor.surface_text: The next contention of Mr. Umrigar that section 3 of the Essential Supplies  Temporary Powers  Act, 1946, amounts to delegation of Legislative power outside the permissible limits is again without any merit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislature laid down policy of maintaining/increasing supplies and equitable distribution at fair prices; delegation guided by this standard; upheld following Delhi Laws Act and Privy Council precedents.

holdings.text: The decision of their Lordships of the Privy Council in Shannons case completely negatives the contention raised regarding the invalidity of section 4

anchor.surface_text: The decision of their Lordships of the Privy Council in Shannons case  3 , completely negatives the contention raised regarding the invalidity of section 4.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 4 specifies classes of officers/authorities for sub-delegation; legislature selects instrumentalities; valid per Shannon case where similar further delegation upheld.

holdings.text: This argument again is not tenable [regarding arbitrary discretion of Textile Commissioner]

anchor.surface_text: This argument again is number tenable. In the first place, the appellants never applied for a permit and made number efforts to obtain one. If the permit had been applied for and refused arbitrarily they might then have had a right to attack the law

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellants never applied for permit so no injury; discretion guided by policy of even distribution; distinguishes Dwarka Prasad as no unrestrained power here; courts can remedy abuse.

holdings.text: the provisions of the Textile Control Order operate as an implied repeal of sections 27, 28 and 41 of the Indian Railways Act and are therefore invalid is also not well founded

anchor.surface_text: The next contention that the provisions of the Textile Control Order operate as an implied repeal of sections 27, 28 and 41 of the Indian Railways Act and are therefore invalid is also number well founded.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Control Order supplements Railways Act provisions without conflict; clauses 3,4,5 add requirements/embargoes not overriding; no repugnancy.

holdings.text: the last contention of Mr. Umrigar that section 6 having been declared invalid, section 3 is inextricably mixed with it and should also have been declared invalid is also not valid
holdings.reasoning_summary: Sections not interdependent; even if, s6 held constitutional independently.

holdings.text: There is no delegation involved in the provisions of section 6 at all and that section could not be held to be unconstitutional on that ground
holdings.reasoning_summary: S6 gives overriding effect (non-obstante) to s3 orders without repealing prior laws; by-passes inconsistencies; any implied repeal by Parliament itself via s6, not delegate.

holdings.text: the provisions of sections 3, 4 and 6 of the Essential Supplies Temporary Powers Act, 1946, are constitutional and the impugned order is also constitutional
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative conclusion affirming constitutionality of ss 3,4,6 and Control Order after rejecting all challenges.
